body:
Hi, Yawei. Thank you for your interest in our work. 
Following the original mean-teacher model, the exponential moving average method is adopted to implement this mechenism. Since the teacher network is updated with the historical parameters from the student network, it thereby plays a role of ensemble model and gradually yields better predictions on the target domain during the training phase.

Hi XUï¼Œ
Thank you for your quick reply! I am just a little confused why the teacher can yield better result than student. In the tranditional mean-teacher mechenism, this is implemented by giving the student harder examples such as more noisy samples, and giving the teacher model clean examples. So that the teacher can always produce more accurate predictions to guide the student. 
In your paper,  the student envolves via the supervised loss and teacher update its paramters from student. No other mechenism to guarantee that the teacher would perform better than student. I think the student might produce better results than the teacher in same case. As a result, learning from a "bad teacher" may hurts the final results on the contrary. How do you think about that? 
Thank you again for your answer!

Best regards,
Yawei

This question also puzzles me for a period. I can't explain it very scientifically, but I am willing to share my intuitive guess. 
Usually, an ensemble model of multiple base networks would yield better predictions than a base network does, since the ensemble model shows more robustness towards noise. In our case, the teacher network is updated with the historical parameters from the student network. It thereby takes the role of ensemble model, and its predictions on the target-domain images are supposed to be closer to the ground-truth, theoretically. Therefore, a natural idea is to adopt the ensemble predictions as the pseudo labels to assist the training of the student network. 
In the practical training phase, since there is no additional restriction for the predictions of the teacher network, the correctness of these pseudo labels can not be always guaranteed, resulting in unstable performance at some iterations.
Thank you for your detailed explaination! It solved some of my confusion!

> Hi XUï¼Œ Thank you for your quick reply! I am just a little confused why the teacher can yield better result than student. In the tranditional mean-teacher mechenism, this is implemented by giving the student harder examples such as more noisy samples, and giving the teacher model clean examples. So that the teacher can always produce more accurate predictions to guide the student. In your paper, the student envolves via the supervised loss and teacher update its paramters from student. No other mechenism to guarantee that the teacher would perform better than student. I think the student might produce better results than the teacher in same case. As a result, learning from a "bad teacher" may hurts the final results on the contrary. How do you think about that? Thank you again for your answer!
> 
> Best regards, Yawei

Hi, @YonghaoXu . The question also confused me. Besides, when I apply this method to unsupervised domain adaptation, the results showed that student model performed better than the teacher one.

Hi @lauraset , thanks for your interest in this work. As discussed with Yawei, although there is no specific design to guarantee that the teacher network would yield more accurate predictions, our observation is the EMA strategy itself would help to bring the knowledge of ensemble learning, which is beneficial to the domain adaptation. 

For your second question, I'm not sure if your task is unsupervised domain adaptation for semantic segmentation or just basic image classification. For the semantic segmentation case, you can check one related work "Self-ensembling with gan-based data augmentation for domain adaptation in semantic segmentation" in ICCV 2019, where the authors provide the testing mIoUs for both the student network and the teacher network at different iterations. You may find that the teacher network would generally outperform the student network most of the time.

Hi, @YonghaoXu. Thank you very much. Your work is great. I understand your explanation.
I still have two issues and hope to know your thoughts.
1. The target images with noise were put into the student model.
 I feel that this step is harmful for the prediction results. 
The step by substracting the mean values and adding a gaussain noise (mean 0, std 0.01)
 on images has a large effect on the image quality, when I test it on the remote sensing image.
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39206462/182154392-addb0161-dd54-4f17-8109-b5c75a66149b.png)
2. Why the teacher net is not set to the training mode?
When testing every 500 steps, the teacher net will be changed to eval  by default. Does this affect the result?
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39206462/182156032-bab386ce-52f3-40fb-ab7a-b8d234b722ff.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39206462/182156071-f544a2e5-583a-4f9b-9c8c-9b15b2fafc44.png)
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/39206462/182156241-a4949b5b-9882-425a-b62b-6c05d25fff49.png)

Hi @lauraset , you are welcome. If Gaussian noise is too strong, you may also consider adding dropout and other image transformations to conduct stochastic augmentation, as introduced in the work of "self ensembling for visual domain adaptation". The key idea here is to introduce random transformations to the input images.

The `eval` mode mainly affects the batch normalization and dropout layers in the network. Since we don't want to update the parameters in the batch normalization layer or activate the dropout layer in the testing phase, we need to turn off them during model evaluation with `model.eval()`. In SEANet, this `eval()` function will not influence the performance. However, if the implementation of the teacher network involves either batch normalization or dropout, we need to pay attention to this switch.

Hi, @YonghaoXu. Thank you very much. I want to know why the `teacher_net.train()` was not added?
If this code was not added, then the batch normalization and dropout layers in the training phase will be fixed after 500 iterations for the teacher_net.

Hi @lauraset , your understanding is correct. If there are batch normalization or dropout layers in the teacher network, we need to switch between `teacher_net.train()` and `teacher_net.eval()` for training and testing. In SEANet, since the VGG-16 model is used to implement both the student and teacher networks, it will not influence the performance without `.train()` or `.eval()`, as there is no batch normalization or dropout layer in the network.
Hi, @YonghaoXu. Oh, you are right. I feel that this step is easily ignored when we use Resnet or other networks with bn and dropout layers. Anyway, thank you very much.
